questions.text: A 30-year-old man diagnosed with Plasmodium falciparum malaria presents with fever and chills after travelling to an endemic area. Which phase of the Plasmodium life cycle occurs in the human host?

choices.text: Formation of sporozoites in the liver
Asexual reproduction of merozoites in red blood cells
Fertilization of gametocytes in the bloodstream

questions.solution:
In the human host, after sporozoites enter the bloodstream and reach the liver, they develop into merozoites. These merozoites invade red blood cells, where they reproduce asexually, leading to the symptoms of malaria.

 

Life Cycle of the Malaria Parasite:

  • The malaria parasite completes its life cycle in two hosts:
    • Definitive Host: Female Anopheles mosquito
    • Intermediate Host: Humans
  • The life cycle consists of two main phases:
    • Asexual Phase (in Humans): Aka schizogony, this occurs in two locations:
      • Erythrocytic Schizogony: Inside red blood cells (RBCs)
      • Exoerythrocytic Schizogony: In liver cells (also called the tissue phase)
    • Sexual Phase (in Mosquito): Sexual forms (gametocytes) develop in human RBCs, followed by maturation and fertilisation in the mosquito, leading to the formation of sporozoites through sporogony.
  • Asexual Phase (Schizogony):
    • Human Infection:
      • Infection occurs via the bite of an infective female Anopheles mosquito.
      • Sporozoites: These infective forms are present in the mosquito's salivary glands and are injected into the human bloodstream during feeding.
    • Pre-erythrocytic Stage (Liver Phase):
      • Sporozoites reach the liver, invade hepatocytes, and enlarge. They undergo multiple nuclear divisions, forming multinucleated schizonts (meronts) that contain 2,000 to 50,000 merozoites.
      • Release of Merozoites: Mature liver schizonts rupture after 6-15 days, releasing merozoites into the bloodstream.
    • Erythrocytic Stage:
      • Merozoites invade RBCs via a process of invagination
      • Development in RBCs: Inside the RBC, merozoites lose internal organelles and transform into ring forms (young trophozoites), which feed on haemoglobin and produce malaria pigment (hemozoin).
      • Maturation: Ring forms develop into late trophozoites and then into mature schizonts containing 8-32 merozoites, which are released upon rupture of the RBC

Malaria Parasite" data-author="" data-hash="9625" data-license="" data-source="" data-tags="" height="640" src="https://image.prepladder.com/notes/91TwpN2CgHbfM9zseW4R1744394484.png" width="936" />

  • Gametogony: After several erythrocytic cycles, some merozoites develop into sexually differentiated forms, the gametocytes.
  • Sexual Phase (Sporogony): When a female Anopheles mosquito consumes parasitised blood, the gametocytes are released in the midgut:
    • Development of gametes: Male gametocytes undergo division to produce microgametes, while female gametocytes mature into macrogametes.
    • Fertilization: A microgamete fertilizes a macrogamete, forming a zygote.
    • Ookinete formation: The zygote transforms into a motile ookinete penetrating the mosquito's stomach wall.
    • Oocyst development: The ookinete develops into an oocyst, where sporozoites are produced.
    • Mature oocyst: Once mature, the oocyst ruptures, releasing sporozoites into the mosquito’s hemocoel and eventually into the salivary glands.

 

Formation of sporozoites in the liver(Option A): Formation of sporozoites occurs in the mosquito, not in the human host.

 

Fertilization of gametocytes in the bloodstream(Option C): Fertilization happens in the mosquito's midgut after a blood meal, not in the human bloodstream.


Development of oocysts in RBCs(Option D): Oocysts develop in the mosquito, not red blood cells; this option is incorrect as oocysts do not form in humans.

questions.text: A 38-year-old man presents with a 7-day history of fever, chills, fatigue, and dark urine after a weekend hiking trip in rural New England. He has a temperature of 102°F (38.9°C), mild splenomegaly, and jaundice. Microscopic findings are noted below. Which of the following statements about this condition is true?

choices.text: Presence of schizonts in blood smear

questions.solution:
The clinical features of fever, chills, dark urine after hiking (with tick exposure), splenomegaly, and jaundice, along with the Maltese cross appearance in the image, indicate a diagnosis of babesiosis caused by Babesia, where sporozoites are the infective form.

 

Babesia

Description

Intraerythrocytic sporozoan parasite

Morphology

Trophozoites (inside RBCs) are pleomorphic (pyriform, ameboid, or spindle-like) and usually in pairs.


 

Life cycle

  • Definitive hosts: Hard ixodid tick (Option A)
  • Intermediate hosts: Rodents or mammal
  • Accidental, dead-end hosts: Human
  • Infective form: Sporozoites (Option D)
  • Sporozoites convert to trophozoites in circulation, which invade the RBCs). (Option C)
 

Clinical features

  • Malaise, fatigue, fever, chills, myalgia, arthralgia, dry cough and anorexia
  • Neck stiffness, sore throat, abdominal pain, jaundice, and anaemia are less common.
  • Severe babesiosis requires hospitalisation.

Types

Babesia microti

Babesia divergens
  • Host: Rodent
  • Mild disease with normal spleen
  • Host: Cattle
  • Severe disease, splenomectised

 

 

Microscopy

Tetrad of rings (known as Maltese cross appearance) are observed.

Management

  • Azithromycin + Atovaquone
  • Clindamycin + Quinine (severe cases)

Complications

  • Renal failure
  • Disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC)
  • Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS)
  • Congestive cardiac failure (CCF)

 

Presence of schizonts in blood smear (Option B) indicates a malarial parasite (Plasmodium), whereas they are absent in babesiosis.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents to the emergency department drowsy and confused, with a 104°F (40°C) fever, severe headache, and neck stiffness. Recently returned from Southeast Asia, she has tachycardia, hypotension, thrombocytopenia, and elevated liver enzymes. A rapid diagnostic test is positive. What is the drug of choice?
questions.solution:
The scenario presenting with fever, headache, neck stiffness, disorientation, hypotension, tachycardia, and a positive rapid test suggests a diagnosis of complicated malaria, for which the drug of choice is intravenous artesunate.

 

Management of Uncomplicated Malaria

As per NVBDCP guidelines (National Vector Borne Disease Control Programme), the following regimen is followed,

 

Plasmodium vivax or ovale

Plasmodium falciparum

Mixed infection

Chloroquine + Primaquine

  • Chloroquine 25 mg for 3 days as 10 mg/kg on day 1, 10 mg/kg on day 2 and 5 mg/kg on day 3.
  • Primaquine 0.25 mg/kg body wt for 14 days

Primaquine + ACT

 

ACT (Artemisinin-based combination therapy):

  • All Indian states (except northeastern): Artesunate (4 mg/kg body weight) + sulfadoxine (25 mg/kg body weight) or pyrimethamine (1.25 mg/kg body weight)
  • Northeastern states: Artemether (20 mg) + Lumefantrine (120 mg)

ACT+ Primaquine 0.25 mg per kg body weight daily for 14 days

 

  • ACT for chloroquine-resistant malaria:
    • Artesunate + Mefloquine
    • Artesunate + Amodiaquine
    • Artesunate + Pyronaridine (used in China)
    • Arterolane + Piperaquine

 

  • In Artemisinin allergic individuals:
    • QDC regimen: Quinidine + Doxycycline + Clindamycin

 

Management of Complicated malaria (acute severe malaria)

  • Supportive and emergency treatment as needed
  • IV Artesunate (drug of choice) (Option B) (Only Artemisinin to be given intravenously; rest are given intramuscularly)
  • IM Artemether
  • IM Arteether
  • IV Quinine in 5% dextrose solution (quinine cause hypoglycemia)

questions.text: A 32-year-old man comes to the emergency department with fever, chills, headache, and muscle pain. His examination shows a temperature of 102°F (39°C), fatigue, splenomegaly, and mild jaundice. A rapid diagnostic test detects the presence of HRP2. Which species is responsible for this finding?
questions.solution:
• The scenario includes fever, chills, splenomegaly, and jaundice, with the detection of HRP-2 (histidine-rich protein-2) in the Rapid Diagnostic Test (RDT), which suggests a diagnosis of malaria caused by Plasmodium falciparum, as HRP-2 is specific to this species.
  • It is an immuno-chromatographic antigen detection test.
  • Sensitivity: 50-100 parasites per microlitre
  • It detects the presence of:
    • Aldolase: All plasmodium spp. (Option A, C, D)
    • pLDH (parasite lactate dehydrogenase): All plasmodium spp. (Option A, C, D)
    • HRP-2 (histidine-rich protein-2): Present only in Plasmodium falciparum (Option B)
  • Interpretation:

Test

Test “A”

Test “B”

Test “C”

Test “D”

Control line

Present

Present

Present

INVALID

(no control line)

Pan malaria

Absent

Present

Present

Plasmodium falciparum

Absent

Absent

Present

Interpretation

Negative test

Positive test

Positive test

(Mixed infection or Plasmodium falciparum only)

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman was recently diagnosed with malaria. A microscopic examination of her blood smear showed infected red blood cells is given below. Based on these findings, which of the following plasmodium species has most likely caused malaria in this patient?
questions.solution:
The microscopic findings described—infected red blood cells of various sizes, multiple ring forms within single red blood cells, and the presence of crescentic (banana-shaped) gametocytes—are characteristic of Plasmodium falciparum.


 

 

Vivax

Falciparum

Malariae

Ovale

RBC size

Enlarged

Normal

Normal

Enlarged with frayed margins

Pigments

Yellowish brown

Dark brown

Schizont

Large (9-10 μm)

Fills the RBC

Contains 12-24 merozoite

Not seen in the periphery

Small (6 μm), almost fills the RBC and contains 8 merozoites

Gametocytes

Spherical

Crescentic

Larger than RBC

Spherical

Ring form

2.5 μm

Occupies ⅓ rd of RBC size

Cytosol opposite to the nucleus is thick

1.5 μm

Occupies ⅙ of RBC size

It may be

  • Multiple forms
  • Accole (attached to RBC membrane)
  • Double dot/headphone shaped with fragment nucleus

Band form

2.5 μm

Occupies ⅓ rd of RBC size

Cytosol opposite to the nucleus is thick

In Plasmodium falciparum, only gametocyte and ring forms are demonstrated in the PBS, as later stages of the erythrocytic cycle occur in deep vessels and not in peripheral blood.

questions.text: An 18-year-old man presents to the hospital with a three-day history of high fever along with severe headaches, muscle aches, and chills every 48 hours. After lab testing, he was started on Artesunate-based combination therapy for malaria. Which of the following tests was most likely used as a gold standard for diagnosing malaria?
questions.solution:
• The gold standard test used for the diagnosis of malaria is microscopy using the Romanowsky stain.
  • This method allows direct visualisation of malaria parasites within red blood cells, providing information about the species, parasite density, and stage of development.
  • It is highly specific and widely used, especially in resource-limited settings.

 

LAB DIAGNOSIS OF MALARIA

Microscopy (Gold standard)
  • Thick smear - for rapid detection of malarial parasite
    • Quantification is done under an oil immersion lens
      • + - 1 to 10 parasites per 100-thick film field
      • ++ - 11 to 100 parasites per 100 thick film field
      • +++ - 10 to 10 per thick film field
      • ++++ - more than 10 per thick film field
    • At least 200 oil immersion fields should be examined before a film is declared negative.
    • It can be used for the detection of malarial parasites as low as 20 parasites / μL

 

  • Thin smear - for determination of plasmodium species
  • Stains used - Romanowsky stain (Leishman, Giemsa or JSB stain)

Quantitative buffy coat test

(Option A)
  • RBCs with parasites are less dense; thus, concentrate just below the buffy coat of WBC on top of the RBC column
  • Acridine orange is used to induce fluorescence on the parasite, giving a fluorescent greenish-yellow appearance on a red background
  • Microscopic examination of a smear made using the buffy coat is done.

Kawamoto fluorescence microscopy

  • Fluorescent dye like acridine orange or benzothiocarboxy purine is used to stain the parasite inside the RBC
  • Parasite DNA is stained fluorescent green, and cytosol RNA is stained red
  • The slide is examined under the fluorescent microscope
  • Used for mass screening in field laboratory

Rapid antigen detection test

  • Immunochromatography is done using monoclonal antibody directed against the parasite antigen

Parasite F test

(Option D)
  • Monoclonal antibody is used to detect histidine-rich protein 2 (HRP-2), which is produced by asexual stages of plasmodium falciparum
    • High sensitivity and specificity
    • Can detect low parasitemia (40 parasite / μL of blood)
    • Can detect only the asexual stage of plasmodium falciparum

Dual antigen test

(Option C)

  • Detects Parasite lactate dehydrogenase (pLDH) and Plasmodium falciparum histidine-rich protein (PfHRP-2)
  • pLDH is produced by trophozoites and gametocytes of all plasmodium spp.
  • PfHRP-2 is produced only by the asexual stage of Plasmodium falciparum.

Molecular method

  • PCR: Used for species determination and detection of drug resistance.
  • DNA probe: Highly sensitive and can detect less than 10 parasites / μL of blood.

questions.text:
A 40-year-old male presents to the emergency department with a high fever, chills, and dark-coloured urine. He recently returned from a trip to a malaria-endemic region in West Africa and self-treated with antimalarial medication. On examination, he is febrile (39.5°C), tachycardic, and has jaundice. Laboratory investigations show:

Hemoglobin: 8 g/dL

LDH: Elevated

Urinalysis: Dark brown urine, positive for haemoglobin.

Total Bilirubin: 4 mg/dL (direct: 1 mg/dL, indirect: 3 mg/dL)

 

Which of the following best explains the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Blackwater fever is a severe form of malaria primarily associated with Plasmodium falciparum infection; it commonly occurs in patients with repeated malaria infections or inadequate treatment with quinine.
  • It is characterised by hemoglobinuria (dark-coloured urine), severe hemolytic anaemia, and jaundice.
  • It results from the severe hemolysis of red blood cells, which releases free haemoglobin into the bloodstream and its subsequent excretion in the urine.

 

Clinical Features and Complications of Malaria

Benign malaria

(Option A)
  • Febrile paroxysms
    • Cold phase: complaints of fatigue, headache, nausea, severe cold, shivering, and rigours.
    • Hot phase: high-grade fever along with dry, hot skin.
    • Sweating phase: this follows with a fall in the fever.
    • The febrile episodes usually coincide with the erythrocytic schizogony.
    • Cytokines like TNF, IL-1 and IFN have important role in the complications of malaria.
  • Anemia
  • Splenomegaly

Malignant Tertian Malaria

Cerebral malaria

  • Hepatosplenomegaly, fever, nausea, headache
  • Presents as diffuse symmetric encephalopathy after 4 to 5 days of high fever with confusion, seizures, paralysis, and coma.

Transfusion malaria

It occurs when malaria parasites are transmitted through contaminated blood transfusions (Trophozoites can be seen).

Complications
  • Black water fever
  • Septicemic malaria: The presence of malaria parasites in the bloodstream, leading to systemic inflammation, septic shock, and multiple organ dysfunction. (Option B)
  • Algid malaria: causes peripheral circulatory failure (option C)
  • Pulmonary edema and ARDS
  • Renal failure
  • Hypoglycemia
  • Severe anemia
  • Hyperpyrexia
  • Metabolic acidosis and shock
  • Bleeding disturbances
  • Hyperparasitemia.
  • Tropical Splenomegaly syndrome:
    • It is a benign condition due to polyclonal B-cell activation in patients with repeated malaria infection. (abnormal immunological response)
    • Commonly seen in tropical regions
    • It is a chronic complication
  • Other chronic complications:
    • Quartan malarial nephropathy
    • It can trigger EBV infection, leading to Burkitt's lymphoma due to significant immunocompromise.

 

species

P.vivax

P.falciparum

P.malariae

P.ovale

P. Knowlesi

Type of fever

Benign tertian fever

(fever occurs every 3rd day)

Malignant tertian fever

(severe form of malaria- cerebral malaria)

benign quartan fever

(fever occurs every 4th day)

Benign tertian fever

Benign quotidian or simian fever

(fever occurs every 24 hrs & not seen in India)

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents to the outpatient clinic with a history of malaria treated six months prior. He reports a sudden onset of fever, chills, and fatigue over the past three days, with symptoms similar to his previous malaria episode. He states that he has been symptom-free since the initial treatment. Which of the following species is most likely responsible for the relapse of Malaria?
questions.solution:
Plasmodium vivax and Plasmodium ovale are the two species capable of causing malaria relapses. They can form hypnozoites, which are dormant forms in the liver that can reactivate months or even years after the initial infection, leading to recurrent symptoms.

 

Relapse in malaria

Recrudescence in malaria

Occurs due to the reactivation of dormant forms of underdeveloped sporozoites, known as hypnozoites, in the liver.

Occurs due to inadequate treatment or resistance to it.

This is seen in (Option A)

  • P. vivax
  • P. ovale

This is seen in (Options B and C)

  • P. falciparum
  • P. malariae

This can happen after 24 weeks to 5

Years of initial attack.

This can happen in 1 to 2 years in P. falciparum and around 50 to 60 years in P. malariae.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man returns from a trip to a malaria-endemic region with a high fever, chills, and headache. Laboratory tests confirm he is infected with Plasmodium falciparum. What is the incubation period for Plasmodium falciparum, and which receptor does it use to bind to red blood cells?
questions.solution:
• For Plasmodium falciparum, the average incubation period is typically around 12 days from the time of infection until the onset of symptoms.
  • The parasite binds to RBCs using the Basigin receptor (CD147), facilitating its entry into the cells.

 

Properties of different species of Plasmodium:

Properties

P.vivax

P.ovale

P.falciparum

P.malariae

Relapse (Hypnozoites)

Seen

Seen

Not seen

Not seen

Recrudescence

Not seen

Not seen

Seen

Seen

Preference

Reticulocytes

Reticulocytes

Young erythrocytes

Old erythrocytes

Erythrocytic Cycle

48 hours

48 hours

36–48 hours

72 hours

Prepatent Period

8 days

9 days

5 days

13 days

Incubation Period

12- 17 days

14-17 days

12 days

28-30 days

Stages found in peripheral blood

Trophozoite,

schizonts,

gametocytes

As in vivax

Ring form, accole form, gametocytes

Band forms

Infected erythrocyte

Enlarged pale

with Schuffner's

dots

Pear-shaped, fimbriated, Schuffner's dots

(Jame's dots)

Normal size, Maurer's cleft

Normal size, Ziemann's stippling

Gametocyte

Spherical, fills

the cell

Similar to but

smaller than vivax

Crescent,

Banana shaped

Similar to but smaller than vivax

Colour of pigment

Yellowish-brown

Yellowish-brown

Black

Dark brown

Prepatent period: The time from the entry of the parasite into the host until it is detectable in peripheral blood.

 

Incubation period: Time interval from the entry of the parasite until the appearance of the first clinical symptoms.

 

Receptors on RBC:

  • Plasmodium vivax: Binds to Duffy antigen (also known as Duffy blood group antigen) on the surface of red blood cells (RBCs)

Plasmodium falciparum: Binds to Basigin (also known as CD147), a protein expressed on the surface of RBCs

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents with a very high fever, chills, and shivering after returning from a tropical region. Laboratory tests confirm infection with a Plasmodium species. It is noted that infected red blood cells adhere to the endothelium of blood vessels. In which species of Plasmodium is this phenomenon primarily observed?
questions.solution:
Plasmodium falciparum is the primary species associated with cytoadherence, where infected red blood cells adhere to endothelial cells in blood vessels. This leads to complications like cerebral malaria due to vessel blockage and reduced blood flow.

 

Pathogenesis of Malignant Malaria:

Cytoadherence:

  • In Plasmodium falciparum malaria, late-stage schizonts secrete proteins that create knob-like protrusions on the surfaces of infected RBCs. This results in the expression of the adhesive protein PfEMP-1 (P. falciparum Erythrocyte Membrane Protein), which makes the infected RBCs sticky.
  • Inflammatory cytokines, particularly IFN-γ, enhance the expression of endothelial receptors such as thrombospondin, E-selectin, VCAM-1, and ICAM-1 in the brain, chondroitin sulfate B in the placenta, and CD36 in most other organs. These receptors promote the cytoadherence of infected RBCs to the endothelium, leading to blockage of capillaries and venules.

Malignant Malaria" data-author="" data-hash="9626" data-license="" data-source="" data-tags="" height="599" src="https://image.prepladder.com/notes/3QJ9nNLIcQ3IAPi7HNlF1744394630.png" width="599" />

Rosette formation: Infected RBCs can adhere to uninfected RBCs, forming rosettes.

 

Auto-Agglutination: The phenomenon where parasitised red blood cells (RBCs) clump together

 

These mechanisms cause capillary plugging and reduced microcirculation in vital organs, including the brain, kidneys, lungs, spleen, intestines, bone marrow, and placenta, resulting in severe complications like cerebral malaria.

 

Other notable virulence factors:

  • Histidine-rich protein II (HRP II)
  • Glycosylphosphatidylinositol (GPI)

questions.text: A 28-year-old pregnant woman presents for a routine check-up with mild flu-like symptoms, fatigue, and swollen lymph nodes. She has a cat at home and frequently handles its litter. Serology shows positive IgM and IgG antibodies for a coccidian parasite. Which of the following statements about this condition is correct?

choices.text: Sporulated oocysts are a non-infective stage.

questions.solution:
• The patient’s symptoms (flu-like illness, fatigue, and lymphadenopathy), with a history of handling cat litter and positive IgG and IgM antibodies, suggest toxoplasmosis caused by Toxoplasma gondii.
  • Bradyzoites (tissue cyst form) are a transmissible stage of Toxoplasma and can infect humans through the consumption of undercooked or raw meat from infected animals.

 

Toxoplasma gondii

Host
  • Definitive host: Cat and other cat species (family Felidae) (Option C)
  • Intermediate host: Humans and animals like sheep, rodents, pigs etc

Infective stages
  • Sporulated oocyst (Option B)
  • Tachyzoites
  • Bradyzoites (tissue cyst)

Modes of transmission

Infective form

Blood Transfusion

  

Tachyzoites

Mother to child (Option A)

Undercooked or raw meat

Sporulated Oocyst

Ingestion of contaminated products

Bradyzoites

questions.text: A 28-year-old man returns from a malaria-endemic region and presents with fever, chills, and fatigue. In the context of malaria, which of the following statements correctly identifies the definitive host and the infective form?

choices.text: Host: Human; Gametocytes in case of transfusion

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Female Anopheles mosquito; Sporozoites

Explanation:

  • Female anopheles mosquitos are the definitive host for malaria parasites.
  • The infective form introduced into the bloodstream by the female Anopheles mosquito is the sporozoite.

 

Malaria:

  • Human malaria is caused by five main Plasmodium species:
    • P.vivax: Benign tertian malaria; fever every 48 hours.
    • P. falciparum: Malignant tertian malaria; severe; fever every 48 hours.
    • P.malariae: Benign quartan malaria; fever every 72 hours.
    • P.ovale: Ovale tertian malaria; fever every 48 hours.
    • P.knowlesi: Quotidian or simian malaria; fever daily; primarily infects monkeys but can affect humans.
  • Plasmodium completes its life cycle in two hosts:
    • Definitive Host: Female Anopheles mosquito (sexual cycle).
    • Intermediate Host: Humans (asexual cycle).
  • Transmission and Infective form:
    • Intermediate Host: Humans
      • Transmission through the bite of an infected female Anopheles mosquito.
      • Infective form: Sporozoites are introduced from the mosquito's salivary glands into the bloodstream during the bite.
    • Blood transfusion and Transplacental transmission:
      • Infective form: Trophozoites / Merozoites
    • Definitive Host: Mosquitos
      • Infective form: Gametocytes

 

Mosquito-Borne Malaria and Blood Transfusion Malaria:

Feature

Mosquito-Borne Malaria

Blood Transfusion Malaria

Mode of Transmission

Mosquito bite

Blood or blood product transfusion

Infective Stage

Sporozoite

Trophozoite

Incubation Period

Long

Short

Severity

Comparatively less

More complications seen

Relapse

May occur

Does not occur

Radical Treatment

Required

Not required

 

Female anopheles mosquito; Trophozoites (Option A): Incorrect – mosquito is correct definitive host, but trophozoites are not the infective form; they are seen in RBCs.

Host: Human; Gametocytes in case of transfusion (Option C): Incorrect – gametocytes are infective to mosquito, not humans; transfusion malaria involves trophozoites/merozoites, not gametocytes.

Host: Human; Merozoites (Option D): Incorrect – humans are intermediate hosts, and merozoites are not the initial infective form (sporozoites are).

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents with two weeks of diarrhoea and abdominal pain after working on a pig farm. His stool sample reveals a ciliate protozoan. Which of the following statements is true about the protozoan?

choices.text: It is the smallest protozoan parasite of humans
The infective form is the trophozoite
Tetracycline is the drug of choice
Transmission is primarily through direct contact

questions.solution:
The given scenario, with symptoms of diarrhoea, a history of working in a pig farm, and ciliate protozoan in the stool sample, points towards Balantidium coli (the only ciliate protozoan parasite of humans), and tetracycline is the drug of choice used in the management.

 

Balantidium coli: (Phylum: Ciliophora)

  • Largest protozoan parasite (Option A) residing in the human large intestine
  • Resides in the large intestine of humans, pigs, and monkeys

Morphology:

  • Trophozoite: Ovoid cell, 60-70 µm in length
    • Two nuclei: a large kidney-shaped macronucleus and a small micronucleus.
    • Motile due to cilia covering the surface.
    • Features include a groove (peristome) leading to the mouth (cytostome) and a short funnel-shaped cytopharynx and cytopyge (analpore) posteriorly.
  • Cyst:
    • Description: Spherical, 40-60 µm in diameter, with a thick double-layered wall.
    • Content: Granular cytoplasm with macronucleus, micronucleus, and vacuoles.
    • Role: Infective stage found in chronic cases and carriers.
  • Life Cycle:
    • Type: Monoxenous (single-host).
    • Habitat: Large intestine
    • Natural Host: Pigs.
    • Accidental Host: Humans.
    • Reservoirs: Pigs, monkeys, rats.
    • Infective Form: Cyst (Option B)
    • Transmission: Infection occurs through ingestion of contaminated food/water containing cysts (Option D)
  • Clinical Features:
    • Most infections are asymptomatic
    • Trophozoites can invade the intestinal mucosa, leading to inflammation, mucosal ulcers, and submucosal abscesses, resembling amebic lesions & presets with:
      • Diarrhea or dysentery
      • Abdominal colic
      • Tenesmus
      • Nausea and vomiting
    • Complications can include secondary bacterial infections, intestinal perforation, and rare involvement of the genital or urinary tracts.
  • Laboratory Diagnosis:
    • The diagnosis was confirmed by identifying trophozoites in diarrheal stools and cysts in formed stools. The trophozoites are large, with distinct nuclei and rapid motility.
    • If stool examination is negative, biopsies from intestinal ulcers may reveal trophozoites and cysts.
  • Treatment:
    • Drug of Choice: Tetracycline (500 mg, four times daily for 10 days).
    • Alternatives include doxycycline, metronidazole, and nitroimidazole.

questions.text: A 42-year-old man presents with severe diarrhoea, abdominal cramps, and weight loss. He recently returned from a tropical region and has a history of HIV with a low CD4 count. The stool analysis finding is given in the image. Which of the following statements about the identified organism is not true?

choices.text: Cotrimoxazole is used for the treatment

questions.solution:
• The clinical scenario of diarrhoea in an immunocompromised host and a stool sample showing oval oocysts suggests cystoisospora belli.
  • The incubation period of cystoisospora is 1-4 days, not 2-14 days.

 

Intestinal Coccidian Parasites:

  • Cryptosporidium species: C.parvum (mammals) & C.hominis (primarily humans)
  • Cyclospora cayetanensis
  • Cystoisospora belli

 

Clinical Features:

  • Immunocompetent Hosts: Symptoms are often mild and may include watery, non-bloody diarrhoea, abdominal pain, nausea, and fever. They are typically self-limiting.
  • Immunocompromised Hosts (e.g., AIDS): Severe, persistent diarrhoea (up to 25 litres/day), significant weight loss & extraintestinal manifestations (Biliary infections)
    • Severity increases with lower CD4+ T cell counts

Features

Cryptosporidium

Cyclospora

Cystoisospora

Transmission

Ingestion of contaminated food/water, autoinfection

Ingestion of contaminated food/water

Ingestion of sporulated oocysts

Infective form

Sporulated oocyst

Sporulated oocyst

Sporulated oocyst

Diagnostic form

Sporulated oocyst

Unsporulated oocyst

Unsporulated oocyst

Incubation Period

2-14 days

1-7 days

1-4 days

Oocyst shape

Round

Round

Oval

Oocyst size

4-6 µm

8-10 µm

20–33 µm

Sporulated oocyst

Four sporozoites

Two sporocysts, each having four sporozoites

Acid-fastness

Uniformly acid-fast

Uniformly acid-fast

Autofluorescence

–

++

Resistance to chlorination

+

–

Sporulation of the oocyst

Inside the host cells (enterocytes)

soil

soil

Zoonotic potential

Yes

No

Treatment

Nitazoxanide

Cotrimoxazole

Cotrimoxazole
 

 

Cotrimoxazole is used for the treatment (Option A):
Correct – TMP-SMX is the drug of choice for treating Cystoisospora belli infection.

Oocysts are usually between 20–33 µm (Option B):
Correct – The oocysts are typically oval and large (20–33 µm), easily visualized with modified acid-fast stain.

The organism shows variable autofluorescence (Option C):
Correct – Cystoisospora belli oocysts exhibit autofluorescence under UV light microscopy.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is not true about the life cycle of Cyclospora?

choices.text: Oocyst shed in the faeces sporulate outside the host
During excystation, 8 sporozoites are released from 2 sporocyst
Sporozoites reproduce asexually in the enterocytes
Autoinfection does not occur with Cyclospora

questions.solution:
In Cyclospora, each oocyst contains 2 sporocysts, but each sporocyst contains 2 sporozoites . Therefore, a total of 4 sporozoites are released upon excystation (not 8 sporozoites).

 

Life Cycle of Cyclospora

life cycle of cyclospora" data-author="" data-hash="11705" data-license="" data-source="" data-tags="May2025" src="https://image.prepladder.com/notes/oTPuSLrjeMCQpc4YIANI1746426652.png" />1. Ingestion of Oocysts: Humans ingest sporulated oocysts from contaminated food or water.

2. Excystation: During excystation of sporulated oocyst of Cyclospora, 2 wheels release 2 sporozoites each

Release of 8 sporozoites from two sporocysts during excystation (Option B) is seen in the life cycle of Isospora (the remaining life cycle is similar to Cyclospora)

3. Invasion of Intestinal Cells: The released sporozoites invade the epithelial cells of the small intestine. (Option C)

4. Asexual Reproduction (Merogony): Merogony occurs to produce meronts 1 and then 2, which contain multiple merozoites.

5. Release of Merozoites: The merozoites are released from the infected epithelial cells into the intestinal lumen.

6. Reinfection of Host Cells: The released merozoites can invade new intestinal epithelial cells, continuing the asexual reproduction cycle.

7. Sexual Reproduction (Gametogony): Some merozoites differentiate into male (microgametes) and female (macrogametes) gametes within the host's intestinal cells

8. Fertilization and Oocyst Formation: The microgametes fertilise the macrogametes to form a zygote, which develops into an unsporulated oocyst.

 

9. Release of Oocysts: Unsporulated oocysts are excreted in the faeces of the infected host; thus, autoinfection is not possible (Option D)

10. Environmental Maturation: The oocysts sporulate in the environment and require a period of maturation before they become infective to another host.

(Option A)

11. Transmission: The mature oocysts can then contaminate food or water, leading to new infections when ingested by humans.

Both Cyclospora and Isospora complete their life cycle in a single host.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the life cycle of Cryptosporidium is not true?

choices.text: It completes sexual and asexual cycles in one host
Oocysts released in faeces are fully mature and infective
Excystation of ingested cyst occurs in the small intestine
Thick-walled oocysts can lead to autoinfection within the host

questions.solution:
• While Cryptosporidium produces both thick-walled and thin-walled oocysts, the thin-walled oocysts contribute to autoinfection within the host.
  • Thick-walled oocysts are typically excreted in the faeces and are primarily responsible for transmission to other hosts.

 

Life Cycle of Cryptosporidium

Cryptosporidium Q6 " data-author="NA" data-hash="9594" data-license="NA" data-source="NA" data-tags="" src="https://image.prepladder.com/notes/MEV2fnXoPvitaGxrnNih1744392729.png" />

1. Ingestion of Infective Oocysts: Humans or animals ingest fully mature (sporulated) oocysts from contaminated water, food, or surfaces.

2. Excystation: In the host’s small intestine, the oocyst releases four sporozoites, which then attach to the intestinal epithelial cells. (Option C)

3. Trophozoite Formation: The sporozoites develop into trophozoites within parasitophorous vacuoles (specialised compartments) in the brush border of the host’s intestinal cells.

4. Asexual Reproduction (Schizogony): Trophozoites undergo asexual reproduction to form type I meronts, each containing eight merozoites.

5. Release of Merozoites: The merozoites are released, infect new epithelial cells, and may undergo schizogony again to form more type I meronts or transition into type II meronts.

6. Sexual Reproduction (Gametogony): Type II meronts release merozoites that invade cells and begin the sexual phase, differentiating into microgametes (male) and macrogametes (female).

7. Fertilization and Oocyst Formation: The microgamete fertilises the macrogamete, forming a zygote that then develops into an oocyst.

8. Sporulation: The zygote undergoes sporogony to form a fully mature, sporulated oocyst containing four sporozoites.

9. Release of Oocysts: Two types of oocysts are produced:

  • Thick-walled oocysts: Excreted in faeces, they are mature and infective and transmit the infection to new hosts. (Option B)
  • Thin-walled oocysts: Remain in the intestine and cause autoinfection, maintaining the cycle within the same host. (Option D)

10. Transmission: Thick-walled oocysts are released into the environment through faeces, where they can infect new hosts upon ingestion.

Both sexual and asexual reproduction occurs within one host (Option A)

questions.text: Which of the following coccidia parasites is the most common cause of diarrhoea in HIV patients?
questions.solution:
Image B shows an oocyst of cryptosporidium, which is the most common opportunistic parasitic infection in HIV-positive / immunocompromised patients.

 

Cryptosporidium

Infective form

Sporulated oocyst in contaminated water

Clinical features

  • In Immunocompetent patients: Self-limited watery diarrhoea.
  • In Immunocompromised patients: Chronic persistent watery diarrhoea.

Microscopy

  • Appearance: Acid-fast, round oocyst
  • Size: 4–6 microns
  • Contents: Each oocyst contains four sporozoites
  • Types of oocyst:
    • Thick-walled - excreted out from host in faeces.
    • Thin-walled - involved in autoinfection.
 

Isospora (Option A)

Cyclospora (Option D)

Sarcocystis (Option C)

Infective form

Sporulated oocyst

Sporulated oocyst

Sporulated oocyst

Clinical features

  • Mild fever with diarrhoea
  • Can cause chronic diarrhoea in the immunocompromised host
  • Formation of sarcocysts within the muscle fibres (Muscular sarcocystosis)
  • Nausea, abdominal pain and diarrhoea (Intestinal sarcocystosis)

Microscopy

Oocyte is oval, acid-fast, 24-36 microns and autofluorescent, containing 8 sporozoites.

Oocyte is round, acid variable, 8-10 microns and autofluorescent, containing 2 - 2 sporozoites in each wheel.

Sarcocysts are present between the muscle fibres; each cyst has numerous merozoites.


 

Pathogens causing diarrhoea in HIV-positive patients

Parasites

Cryptosporidium parvum (Most common)

Isospora belli

Cyclospora

Giardia lamblia

Entamoeba histolytica

Microsporidia spp

Bacteria

Shigella species (Most common)

Salmonella species

Campylobacter jejuni

Viruses

Cytomegalovirus

Adenovirus

Fungi

Histoplasma

Candida

questions.text: A 26-year-old pregnant woman in her second trimester presents with eye pain, photophobia, and headache. Fundoscopy reveals a fluffy white lesion and optic disc swelling. To rule out toxoplasmosis, her physician orders a serological test. Which of the following tests is the gold standard for diagnosis of toxoplasmosis?

choices.text: PCR of amniotic fluid for toxoplasma DNA

questions.solution:
• The Sabin-Feldman dye test is the gold standard for diagnosing Toxoplasma gondii infection due to its high specificity.
  • It is a complement fixation test.
  • Based on the principle that antibodies specific to Toxoplasma gondii prevent the parasite from absorbing alkaline methylene blue.
    • Antibody present: Colour will be absent.
    • Antibody absent: Colour will be present.

Diagnosis of Toxoplasmosis

Antenatal

USG

  • Done at 20-24 weeks of gestation and repeated every 2-4 weeks
  • It helps detect lesions of congenital infection, such as
    • Hydrocephalus
    • Cerebral calcifications
    • Ascites

Serology

ELISA (Enzyme-Linked Immunosorbent Assay) or IFA (Immunofluorescence Assay) is done using maternal serum to detect IgM and IgG

PCR
  • Amniotic fluid can be used to detect Toxoplasma DNA, which can confirm the diagnosis.
  • It is not done routinely as it is invasive and expensive, and other safer options are available.

Postnatal diagnosis

Serology

Newborn Sera and maternal sera are both used to detect

  • IgG >= 1000: Possible infection
  • IgM >= 1:4 after 2 weeks of age: Indicates probable diagnosis
  • IgA: Disappears within 10 days of birth; thus, persistence indicates postnatal infection
 

Sabin-Feldman test - Complement fixation test

Other tests

  • Animal inoculation (no longer done for clinical diagnosis)
  • Skin test of Frenkel
  • Microscopy of samples to detect tachyzoites using Giemsa or PAS

questions.text: An asymptomatic newborn is evaluated for congenital infections soon after birth as his mother was diagnosed with toxoplasmosis during her third trimester. Serologic tests of the infant also confirm congenital toxoplasmosis. Which of the following findings is least likely to develop in this patient?
questions.solution:
In congenital toxoplasmosis, common findings include chorioretinitis, hydrocephalus, and intracranial calcifications (typically diffuse or scattered). However, periventricular calcifications are more characteristic of congenital cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection rather than toxoplasmosis.

 

 

Congenital Toxoplasmosis

Congenital CMV

Clinical features

  • Classical triad: Chorioretinitis + Hydrocephalus/Microcephaly + Intracerebral calcification
  • Hepatosplenomegaly
  • Intrauterine growth restriction
  • Ocular manifestations:
    • Scotoma
    • Glaucoma
    • Strabismus
    • It usually causes B/L chorioretinitis.
    • May lead to blindness.


 
  • Jaundice
  • Petechial rash
  • Hepatosplenomegaly
  • Chorioretinitis
  • Cataracts
  • Microcephaly
  • Mental retardation
  • Sensorineural hearing loss (SNHL)

 

Imaging

Intracerebral calcifications

Periventricular calcifications

Treatment

Oral pyrimethamine + sulfadiazine

Ganciclovir

Valganciclovir

Foscarnet

Clinical features common in both

  • Chorioretinitis
  • Microcephaly
  • Mental retardation
  • Hepatosplenomegaly

 

The Gregg triad is a classic set of three symptoms associated with rubella, seen in infants whose mothers contracted the rubella virus during pregnancy. The Gregg triad consists of:

1. Deafness

2. Cataract

3. Cardiac anomalies

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman who handles her pet cat and is now pregnant is concerned about serious infections that could affect her fetus, including toxoplasmosis. During which stage of pregnancy is the risk of transplacental infection with toxoplasmosis highest?
questions.solution:
In Toxoplasma gondii infections during pregnancy, the risk of transplacental transmission to the fetus is highest in the third trimester.

 

Toxoplasmosis in pregnancy

Mother

Usually asymptomatic but can transmit the disease to the infant.

Infective form

Trophozoite crosses the placenta to infect the neonate.

Risk of transplacental infection based on time of infection of the mother

Transplacental infection can occur at any time during the pregnancy, but the gestational age influences the risk of transmission (Option D).

 

As the gestational age increases, the risk of transmission increases, but the severity of neonatal disease decreases.

 

Pre-pregnancy (Option B)

  • Very low chance of transmission (immunocompromised mother)
 

First trimester

  • Minimal risk of transmission (Option A).
  • If transmitted, it results in more severe fetal complications.
 

Third trimester

  • Maximum risk of transmission (Option C).
  • If transmitted, it is usually asymptomatic in newborns.

 

  • First Trimester:
    • Toxoplasmosis: High risk of severe fetal consequences if infection occurs early.
    • Rubella: Greatest risk of congenital defects if contracted during the first trimester.
    • CMV: Risk of transmission increases with gestational age but can lead to severe outcomes if contracted early.
  • Second Trimester:
    • Syphilis: Can be transmitted at any stage, but early detection and treatment are crucial to prevent fetal complications.
    • Varicella Zoster Virus (VZV): Risk of congenital varicella syndrome is present if the mother contracts the virus during this period.
  • Third Trimester:
    • Herpes Simplex Virus (HSV): Primarily transmitted during delivery; however, maternal infection late in pregnancy poses a significant risk for neonatal herpes.
    • Group B Streptococcus (GBS): Commonly associated with infections during labor and delivery rather than in utero transmission.
